ranked_diseases.explanation: Most common form of juvenile macular dystrophy, presenting with reduced visual acuity and macular changes. Age of onset can vary from childhood to adulthood, fitting the patient's presentation.
Autosomal dominant macular dystrophy that can present in adulthood with reduced visual acuity and characteristic macular lesions. Compatible with patient's age and phenotype.

ranked_diseases.disease_name: Pattern dystrophy of retinal pigment epithelium
ranked_diseases.explanation: Adult-onset macular dystrophy typically presenting in the 5th-6th decade with reduced visual acuity and various macular patterns. Age matches well with patient.
Autosomal dominant macular dystrophy with typical onset in the 4th-5th decade, presenting with reduced visual acuity and macular changes. Age-appropriate for this patient.
Adult-onset macular dystrophy with drusen-like deposits, presenting with gradual visual loss. Can manifest in the 5th-6th decade matching patient's age.
Adult-onset vitelliform macular dystrophy caused by PRPH2 mutations, presenting with reduced visual acuity and macular lesions similar to Best disease.
Autosomal dominant macular dystrophy with variable expressivity. Can present with reduced visual acuity, though typically stable and congenital.
Adult-onset vitelliform macular dystrophy presenting with bilateral macular lesions and reduced visual acuity, typically in the 4th-6th decade.
